channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Critic of Pakistani Military Wounded in Karachi Attack
item.description: The brother of the Pakistani journalist who was shot accused the chief of Pakistan’s intelligence service of being responsible for the attack.
item.dc:creator: By SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: 13 Suspected Militants Killed in Yemen
item.description: An airstrike killed 13 suspected Al Qaeda militants and three civilians in Yemen.
item.category: Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Pro-Russian Forces Work on Consolidating Power
item.description: In towns that form the core of the area under pro-Russian militant control, pressure mounted on political dissenters and the media in ways that are commonplace in Russia.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:description: An Orthodox priest in Donetsk, Ukraine, blessed pro-Russian activists on Saturday who are part of the city’s occupying force.

item.title: In Cold War Echo, Obama Strategy Writes Off Putin
item.description: President Obama is focused on isolating Russia by cutting off its economic and political ties to the outside world, limiting its expansionist ambitions and effectively making it a pariah state.
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER

item.title: Breaking Proud Tradition, Captains Flee and Let Others Go Down With Ship
item.description: Lee Jun-seok became the second sea captain in two years to flee a sinking vessel when he left a South Korean ferry as terrified passengers were still struggling to get off.
item.dc:creator: By CHRISTOPHER DREW and JAD MOUAWAD
item.media:credit: Uriel Sinai for The New York Times
item.media:description: A sketch of the capsized ferry stood near relatives waiting for missing passengers in South Korea.

item.title: Covert Inquiry by F.B.I. Rattles 9/11 Tribunals
item.description: The F.B.I.’s inquiry became the focus of the pretrial hearings at Guantánamo this week, after the contractor who was visited by the F.B.I. disclosed it to the defense team.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By MATT APUZZO

item.title: News Analysis: Torment on the Stand, but Is It an Act?
item.description: Oscar Pistorius is either a traumatized person or a good actor. His histrionics are hard to read.
item.dc:creator: By SARAH LYALL
item.media:credit: Pool photographs by Themba Hadebe and Siphiwe Sibeko (right)
item.media:description: Oscar Pistorius reacting to testimony given at his murder trial on April 7.

item.title: The Lede: Turkish Women Use Twitter to Fight Sexual Harassment
item.description: Thousands of Turkish women have taken part in a Twitter campaign to voice outrage at men who invade their space by spreading their legs while sitting next to them on buses and trains.
item.dc:creator: By CEYLAN YEGINSU

item.title: Held in Syria, 4 Journalists Are Released
item.description: After 10 months in captivity in Syria, the French journalists were released on the Turkish-Syrian border on Friday.
item.dc:creator: By ALISSA J. RUBIN

item.title: Ferry Pilot Was Negotiating Perilous Waterway for First Time, Prosecutors Say
item.description: A 26-year-old third mate was steering a South Korean ferry through a notoriously treacherous waterway for the first time when it tilted and sank, prosecutors said on Saturday.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN and SU-HYUN LEE

item.title: Forget the Car. In Slovakian Lottery, Real Prize Goes to Tax Man.
item.description: The idea of a new lottery in Slovakia is to encourage citizens to collect sales receipts and register them with the government, forcing restaurant and shop owners to pay the taxes they owe.
item.dc:creator: By SUZANNE DALEY and RAPHAEL MINDER
item.media:credit: Maciek Nabrdalik for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jozef Lazarcik, left, won a car after registering only nine receipts with Slovakia’s new tax lottery.

item.title: Captain and Two Crew Members Are Arrested in Korean Ferry Sinking
item.description: The captain, Lee Jun-seok, 69, was charged with abandoning the boat and its passengers at a time of crisis, among other counts, according to prosecutors.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN and SU-HYUN LEE
item.media:credit: South Korean Coast Guard, via European Pressphoto Agency
item.media:description: The Korean ferry's captain, Lee Jun-seok, was seen being rescued from the sinking vessel on Wednesday.

item.title: Deadliest Day: Sherpas Bear Everest’s Risks
item.description: An avalanche that left at least 13 dead has focused attention on the Sherpas, skilled high-altitude climbers who put themselves at great risk for the teams that pay them.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY and GRAHAM BOWLEY
item.media:description: Mount Everest in 2009. An avalanche swept down a slope of Mount Everest on Friday, killing guides.

item.title: Deadly Clash Reported on Border of China and Vietnam
item.description: Seven people died during the gunfight Friday, which began after migrants grabbed one or more assault rifles from the guards and began firing, the reports said.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Chinese Court Sentences 4 Activists to Jail
item.description: The sentencing is part of a clampdown on the New Citizens Movement, which has called on government officials to disclose their financial assets.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: Police officers outside the courthouse in Beijing on Apr. 8 during Ding Jiaxi's trial.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Prominent Scientist Welcomes Soil Pollution Report
item.description: A leading Chinese scientist welcomed the release of a government report on contaminants in soil, a first in the country, but questioned why it had been done in such an understated manner.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: Chimneys from a state-owned lead smelter and foundry alongside agricultural fields in Anhui Province. The sign warns against constructing residential buildings within 800 meters.

item.title: Italian Bank Proposes Increased Stock Offering
item.description: The plan to issue $6.9 billion in new stock comes as the bank fights to avoid nationalization and braces for stress tests of its balance sheet by European regulators.
item.category: Monte dei Paschi di Siena SpA
item.dc:creator: By GAIA PIANIGIANI and DAVID JOLLY
item.media:description: The headquarters of Monte dei Paschi in Siena, Italy. The bank, Italy’s third largest, must begin repaying a European bailout.

item.title: Snowden Defends Query to Putin on Surveillance
item.description: Edward J. Snowden insisted that he had been trying to hold Russia’s government to account over its surveillance practices, as he did with the Obama administration.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By JOHN HARNEY

item.title: U.S. Plans Military Drills in Eastern Europe
item.description: The moves in Poland and Estonia are part of a broader effort to strengthen NATO’s air, sea and land presence in the region in response to Russia’s military actions in and near Ukraine.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: U.S. Military Deaths in Afghanistan
item.description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,302 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: In Pistorius Trial, Critics See a Justice System Favoring the Rich and Famous
item.description: The murder trial of the double-amputee sprinter has highlighted the wide gap between celebrity justice and the treatment meted out to ordinary South Africans.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: Oscar Pistorius at his murder trial on Thursday in Pretoria, South Africa. He was granted bail last year on lenient conditions.

item.title: World Briefing: Algerian President Wins a Fourth Term
item.description: President Abdelaziz Bouteflika has won a fourth term as Algeria’s leader, receiving 81.5 percent of the vote, officials said Friday.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By AMIR JALAL ZERDOUMI

item.title: World Briefing: Viral Disease Spreads to Southeast Asia
item.description: The viral disease known as Middle East Respiratory Syndrome has reached Asia, according to reports from Malaysia and the Philippines.
item.dc:creator: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.

item.title: Paper Shows U.S.-Flagged Plane in Iran Has Ties to Ghana
item.description: The ownership ties between a Utah bank and a Ghanaian company raise questions about the role of sanctions.
item.dc:creator: By JESSICA SILVER-GREENBERG

item.title: Pro-Russian Insurgents Balk at Terms of Pact in Ukraine
item.description: A U.S.-backed deal to settle the crisis in eastern Ukraine fell flat but appeared to arrest, at least temporarily, the momentum of separatist unrest in the region.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS and ANDREW E. KRAMER
